V.iii.5.5.b
.
Testing Requirements for Peripheral Arterial Disease
Under
38 CFR 4.104, DC 7114, Note 2
, peripheral arterial disease may be evaluated utilizing ankle brachial index, ankle pressure, toe pressure, or transcutaneous oxygen tension values.
The ankle/brachial index is the most common type of testing for evaluating peripheral arterial disease.  In some situations, ankle/brachial index measurement is not appropriate for a given disability.  In those cases, ankle pressure, toe pressure, or transcutaneous oxygen tension values are more appropriate tests.
If the ankle pressure, toe pressure, and/or transcutaneous oxygen tension measurements are not of record, evaluate based on the ankle/brachial index unless the examiner indicates that one of the other tests is necessary.
If more than one test result is available, evaluate using the test result that results in the highest evaluation.
